repository.corpname: Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation & Archives

did.physdesc: Albumen print, cartes-de-visite (card photographs), gelatin silver print, lithographs, photographs, photomechanical processes, photomechanical prints.
did.abstract: Photographs of water turbines, canal construction and repair, storm damage, as well as other subjects. Most of the photographs were taken in Lawrence, Massachusetts.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Essex Company was charted in 1845 to build a dam and canals on the Merrimack River to provide power for textile mills, with the intent to build a planned city, Lawrence, Massachusetts. The company also built several mills and mill machinery.

In the 1830s Daniel Saunders began buying land on either side of the Merrimack River between Lowell and Andover, in order control the water power rights. With his son, Daniel Saunders, Jr., his uncle, J. Abbot Gardiner, and John Nesmith, he established the Merrimack River Power Association. Saunders then approached the Lawrence brothers (Samuel, Amos, and Abbott) and the Boston Associates. The Boston Associates bought the Merrimack Water Power Association and renamed it the Essex Company.

When Lawrence was incorporated as a town in 1847 and a city in 1853, the Essex Company laid out the streets and built much of the infrastructure. The City Hall and churches were built on land donated by the Essex Company.

Unique among the mill towns in New England, Lawrence, Massachusetts, was planned and development controlled due to the fact that the Essex Company owned most of the land along both sides of the river. The company further controlled development by buying, jointly with Lowell's Proprietors of Locks and Canals, land and water rights along the Merrimack River up to Lake Winnipesaukee, in New Hampshire. This led to the Essex Company becoming a pioneer in water and sewage treatment, developing the United States' first slow sand filter for drinking water.
In 1979 a hydroelectric company acquired the Essex Company in order to make use of the dam.
The above organizational history was condensed from The Lawrence History Center's Administrative History for their Records of the Essex Company of Lawrence, Massachusetts, 1845-1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of water turbines, canal construction and repair, flooding from spring runoff (freshets), ice dams, various buildings in the Lawrence, Massachusetts, area. Also included are photographs of scenery, family groups, houses, and othe buildings. Hurricane and tornado damage are also pictured.
Boxes 1 through 10 of this collection are prints made from the glass plate negatives in Collection 6633 GPN.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Not all photographs in this collection are described. Only those that had descriptions from the American Textile History Museum have been described. The prints in boxes 1 through 10, which are from the glass plate negatives in collection 6633 GPN: Essex Company Glass Plate Negatives, have not been described. The described photographs may include some that were printed from negatives in 6633 GPN.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the collections in the Kheel Center is restricted. Please contact a reference archivist for access to these materials.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection must be used in keeping with the Kheel Center Information Sheet and Procedures for Document Use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Essex Company Photographs #6633 P. Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related Collections: 6633 G: Essex Company Graphics 6633 GPN: Essex Company Glass Plate Negatives 6633: Essex Company Records 6633 PUBS: Essex Company Publications Records of the Essex Company of Lawrence, Massachusetts, 1845-1987, Lawrence History Center Immigrant City Archives an Museum, Lawrence, Massachusetts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous prints from glass plate negatives in 6633 GPN, from unknown boxes

did.unittitle: Item 1: Essex Company workers repairing the Lawrence Dam, Lawrence, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy print of: Essex Company workers repairing the Lawrence Dam, Lawrence, Mass. Lawrence Eagle-Tribune (photographer). Gelatin silver print. Image depicts several Essex Company workers repairing the Lawrence Dam on the Merrimack River in Lawrence, Mass. The workers have been lowered almost to the foot of the falls to repair a wooden structure. 20.25 x 25.25 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 2: Essex Company workers on the Lawrence Dam, Lawrence, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy print of: Essex Company workers on the Lawrence Dam, Lawrence, Mass. Lawrence Eagle-Tribune, photographer. Gelatin silver print. Image depicts several Essex Company workers working on flashboards of the Lawrence Dam on the Merrimack River in Lawrence, Mass. Photo taken in winter or early spring of 1982; workers in winter gear and ice visible just above flashboards. 25.25 x 20.25 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 1: View of Kingston Street shanty
Item 1: Samuel Dale Stevens, reading "New England Homestead"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Samuel Dale Stevens, reading "New England Homstead." Halftone, [1968]. Image depicts Samuel Dale Stevens (1859-1922) sitting in a chair, holding a copy of "New England Homestead" in his right hand. Stevens is dresssed in a dark, three-piece suit, white shirt, and tie. He wears a wedding ring on his left hand. Samuel Dale Stevens began working at M.T. Stevens (later M.T. Stevens & Sons Co.) in 1878; he became a partner with Nathaniel Stevens in 1885. See Collection 6896 P: Stevens Companies Photographs, for the original photograph from which this print was made. Fig. 5 from "S.D. Stevens and his spinning wheel collection," by Horatio Rogers, published in Essex Institute Historical Collections, January 1969, pp. 31-36. Copy A. 15.5 x 23.5 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 2: Samuel Dale Stevens, reading "New England Homestead"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Samuel Dale Stevens, reading "New England Homstead." Halftone, [1968]. Image depicts Samuel Dale Stevens (1859-1922) sitting in a chair, holding a copy of "New England Homestead" in his right hand. Stevens is dresssed in a dark, three-piece suit, white shirt, and tie. He wears a wedding ring on his left hand. Samuel Dale Stevens began working at M.T. Stevens (later M.T. Stevens & Sons Co.) in 1878; he became a partner with Nathaniel Stevens in 1885. See Collection 6896 P: Stevens Companies Photographs, for the original photograph from which this print was made. Fig. 5 from "S.D. Stevens and his spinning wheel collection," by Horatio Rogers, published in Essex Institute Historical Collections, January 1969, pp. 31-36. Copy B. 15.5 x 23 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 3: Construction of Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Construction of Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H. Gelatin silver print snapshot, 1941. Image depicts the construction of the Franklin Falls Dam in Franklin, N.H. This photo, taken May 20, 1941, shows the rock berm on the left bank in the rear of the dam. Numerous cars and trucks parked in the foreground; several cranes visible in the middle ground. The dam was constructed by the Army Corps of Engineers for flood control of the Pemigewasset River; construction began in November 1939 and was completed in October 1943. The Pemigewasset River joins with the Winnipesaukee River about three miles downstream to form the Merrimack River. See Item 4, in this folder, for an almost identical view. 13.25 x 8.5 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 4: Construction of Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Construction of Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H. Gelatin silver print snapshot. Image depicts the construction of the Franklin Falls Dam in Franklin, N.H. This photo, taken May 20, 1941, is taken from a slightly different angle than Item 3, in this folder. Over the roof of the building at the left is the entrance channel to the waste gates. Numerous cars and trucks parked in the foreground; several cranes visible in the middle ground. The dam was constructed by the Army Corps of Engineers for flood control of the Pemigewasset River; construction began in November 1939 and was completed in October 1943. The Pemigewasset River joins with the Winnipesaukee River about three miles downstream to form the Merrimack River. 13.25 x 8.5 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 5: Construction of Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H., showing bridge in background

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Construction of Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H., showing bridge in background. Gelatin silver print snapshot. Image depicts the construction of the Franklin Falls Dam in Franklin, N.H. This photo, taken May 20, 1941, shows the intake to the waste gate at the extreme left over the roof of the building. This photo shows bridge in the background. The waste gates are at the end of the curved wall. Cars and trucks parked in the foreground. The dam was constructed by the Army Corps of Engineers for flood control of the Pemigewasset River; construction began in November 1939 and was completed in October 1943. The Pemigewasset River joins with the Winnipesaukee River about three miles downstream to form the Merrimack River. 13.25 x 8.5 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 6: Billboard describing the construction of the Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Billboard describing the construction of the Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H. Gelatin silver print snapshot. Image depicts a billboard that describes the construction of the Franklin Falls Dam in Franklin, N.H. Billboard shows the process of construction and gives statistics regarding the project. Note the probable completion date of June 30, 1942. The dam was constructed by the Army Corps of Engineers for flood control of the Pemigewasset River; construction began in November 1939 and was completed in October 1943. The Pemigewasset River joins with the Winnipesaukee River about three miles downstream to form the Merrimack River. This photo was taken on May 20, 1941. 13.25 x 8.5 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 7: Partially completed Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Partially completed Franklin Falls Dam, Franklin, N.H. Gelatin silver print snapshot. Image depicts the ongoing construction of the Franklin Falls Dam in Franklin, N.H. The waste gates are at the extreme right; at the extreme left is the partially completed dam. Several cranes are visible in the photo; piles of lumber and ohter construction materials are in the fore- and middle ground. This photo taken May 20, 1941. The dam was constructed by the Army Corps of Engineers for flood control of the Pemigewasset River; construction began in November 1939 and was completed in October 1943. The Pemigewasset River joins with the Winnipesaukee River about three miles downstream to form the Merrimack River. 13.25 x 8.5 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver print. Image depicts Newfound Lake in Bristol, N.H., looking north from the southerly end of the lake. Photo taken May 20, 1941. 13.25 x 8.5 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver print snapshot, May 20, 1941. Image depicts a view of the Lawrence Dam on the Merrimack River in Lawrence, Mass., taken May 20, 1941 at 7:30 pm. Written on reverse: "Lawrence Dam May 20, 1941 7:30 PM About 5 inches of water over flash boards." 13 x 8.5 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 10: John R. Rollins, paymaster for the Essex Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Yeaw & Co., No. 166 Essex Street, Lawrence, Mass. Albumen print carte de visite, [1863-66?]. Image depicts a bearded Rollins standing, with his arms crossed, in a Civil War (Union) uniform with ceremonial sword hanging at his left side. 5.5 x 8.75 cm. (w/out mount); 6 x 10 cm. (w/mount).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographed by Fred M. Smith, 27 Tremont Row,Boston, Mass. Gelatin silver print, ca. 1880. Image depicts the Pemberton Mills in Lawrence, Mass., showing six-story brick building with two fire escapes; the word Pemberton is in stone on the short side of the building on the right. A railroad car and railroad tracks are on the right next to the canal. Building is surrounded by other brick mill buildings; the old Washington Mills can be seen on the far right. This would be the mill built after the collapse of the prior Pemberton Mill in January 1860. 33.5 x 25.5 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No. 2 Essex Company North Canal [Lawrence] July 27, 1902. View looking upstream showing general arrangement of enlarging mouth pieces at sluiceways, entrance to canal. Surface of water at about (20.5)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Whitney & Son, Cambridge [Mass.] photographer. Gelatin silver print, [after 1906]. Image depicts the Longfellow Bridge, connecting Boston to Cambridge, Mass., from the Boston side. The bridge was known as the Cambridge Bridge until 1927 when it was renamed the Longfellow Bridge. 24.25 x 18.5 cm. (w/out mount); 35 x 27.25 cm. (w/mount).

did.unittitle: Item 8: View of Essex Company Dam, Lawrence, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver print. Image depicts frozen falls at the Essex Company dam in Lawrence, Mass., March 3, 1905. Image actually made of two prints joined together. See Item 9, in this folder, for a better print taken at a slightly different angle. 29.25 x 11 cm. (w/out mount); 40.5 x 22 cm. (w/mount).

did.unittitle: Item 9: View of Essex Company Dam, Lawrence, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver print. Image depicts frozen falls at the Essex Company dam in Lawrence, Mass., March 3, 1905. Image actually made of two prints joined together. See Item 8, in this folder, for another print (not as clear) taken at a slightly different angle. 30 x 11 cm. (w/out mount); 40.5 x 21.5 cm. (w/mount).

did.unittitle: Item 26: View of unidentified man playing golf
Item 27: Group of Essex Company employees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Albumen print, ca. 1878. Image depicts a posed group of men, most of whom (probably all) were employed by the Essex Company of Lawrence, Mass. Identified on reverse: front row, left to right: C. W. Kempton, Fred Chabot, Nelson Harris, and Thomas Holmes; back row, left to right: Fred Whittier, C. J. O'Reilly, Richard A. Hale, and James O'Reilly. In the 1877 Lawrence, Mass., directory, James L. O'Reilly, Whittier, and Hale were all listed as students at the Essex Company, while Fred Chabot was listed as an assistant, and Holmes as a gate tender. By 1881, Hale and Whittier had joined Chabot as assistants, while Holmes remained a gate tender. All of the men wear dark suits with wide lapels, white shirts, and dark ties (except for James O'Reilly and Holmes, who wear light ties). Several wear dark overcoats. Hale (1852-1928) wears pince nez, the ony one in the group wearing spectacles of any kind; he eventually became chief engineer of the Essex Company in 1921. Most of the men have mustaches; Holmes has a beard. 23 x 18 cm. (w/out mount); 24.25 x 19.5 cm. (w/mount).

Item 1: View of Lower End of North Canal
Item 3: View of men repairing flash boards on dam
Item 4: View of men repairing flash boards on dam
Item 5: View of men repairing flash boards on dam
Item 6: View of men repairing flash boards on dam
Item 7: View of scow used to repair flash boards at top of Lawrence Dam, Lawrence, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver contact print, [197-?; original glass plate negative ca.1905-10?]. Image depicts a scow used on the Merrimack River to repair the flashboards at the top of the Lawrence Dam (formally known as the Merrimack River Dam) in Lawrence, Mass. Several factory chimneys and other buildings visible on the far side of the river in the background. At least eight men are on the scow, some holding sledgehammers; see Item 8, in this folder, for another view of this scow. Unclear when the contact print was made, but the original image dates from approximately 1905-1910. 25.25 x 20.25 cm.

did.unittitle: Item 8: Scow used to repair flash boards at top of Lawrence Dam with laborers, Lawrence, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver contact print, [197-?; original glass plate negative ca.1905-10?]. Image depicts a scow used on the Merrimack River to repair the flashboards at the top of the Lawrence Dam (formally known as the Merrimack River Dam) in Lawrence, Mass. Buildings visible on the far side of the river in the background. A dozen men are on the scow, some holding sledgehammers; see Item 7, in this folder, for another view of this scow. Unclear when the contact print was made, but the original image dates from approximately 1905-1910. 25.25 x 20.5 cm.
